Research Paper The impact of indium and manganese modifiers on the catalytic properties of zinc-alumina propane dehydrogenation catalysts Yury A. Supported zinc-containing catalysts are considered as a viable alternative to the currently-deployed Cr-based (toxic) and Pt-based (costly) catalysts of alkane dehydrogenation, as reflected also in the increased number of reports related to the Zn-based catalysts in recent years. Here, we present a study of alumina-supported Zn-In and Zn-Mn propane dehydrogenation (PDH) catalysts prepared by the tailored methods. Specifically, the introduction of zinc relied on the chemical vapor deposition (CVD, using Zn vapor) onto alumina or alumina-supported indium or manganese materials, the latter two prepared by the impregnation of alumina with aqueous solutions of the respective metal nitrates followed by the calcination and hydrogen treatment. Alternatively, both zinc and indium were introduced by the co-impregnation of alumina with aqueous zinc and indium nitrates. The PDH tests revealed that the “dilution” of the active Zn2+ surface sites with In+ cations lead to a significant improvement in the catalytic performance, i.e., the introduction of In+ increased propene selectivity and attenuated the undesirable cracking and hydrogenolysis side reactions as well as decreased coke formation. In contrast, Mn2+ cations improved the catalytic properties of Zn2+ surface sites to a lesser extent than In+ cations. All prepared catalysts were characterized by DRIFT (diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform) spectroscopy of the adsorbed CO and H2 probe molecules. It was found that surface In+ and Mn2+ cations affect Zn2+ sites (electronic and geometric effect), which can be assessed from the position of the IR bands of zinc hydridespecies, formed due to the heterolytic hydrogen dissociation on the Zn2+ active sites. The effect of In and Mn dopants also was confirmed by the molecular DFT simulation. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Zinc active sites Propane dehydrogenation Zinc surface hydrides Hydrogen dissociation Carbon monoxide adsorption Data availability All data underlying the results are available as part of the article and no additional source data are required. Introduction The selective nonoxidative catalytic dehydrogenation of light paraffins (C2–C5) to the respective olefins is an actively researched field owing primarily to the increasing demand for (more) efficient conversion of gaseous hydrocarbon feedstocks into platform chemicals such as propene, propene oxide, acrylonitrile, acrylic acid, cumene, etc. In particular, much of research efforts in the past decades have been focused on the nonoxidative propane dehydrogenation (PDH) reaction. Such industrial PDH processes operate at temperatures above 773 K and typically deploy supported catalysts based on chromium oxide or platinum [1,2]. While Pt-based catalysts exhibit good activity and stability, Pt is costly and scarce. In the same time, catalysts containing chromium oxide suffer from the toxicity concerns associated with Cr(VI). In addition, chromium-based PDH catalysts deactivate notably with time on stream due to coking, which necessitates catalyst regeneration by air treatment. These considerations motivate the search for alternative PDH catalysts. Materials containing various metal oxides have been investigated for PDH, for instance, catalysts based on gallium oxide, molybdenum oxide or indium oxide have been considered [1]. In this context, zinc-based materials have emerged as promising alternative catalysts for nonoxidative PDH, aided by the low cost and low toxicity of Zn. Processes that rely on the dehydrogenation properties Zn-based catalysts include the conversion of light alkanes to aromatics over zinc-exchanged ZSM-5 zeolites [3]. Furthermore, moderate activity and high olefin selectivity was reported for Zn/Al2O3 [4,5] and Zn/SiO2 [6,7] PDH catalysts. Supporting ZnO on ZrO2 oxide has been reported to yield highly active and selective PDH catalysts as well [8]. Recently a new industry-friendly approach for the preparation of durable supported zinc-based catalysts for propane dehydrogenations was reported [9]. We have recently reported that supporting zinc on alumina using chemical vapor deposition (CVD) of zinc provides catalysts with a high concentration of Zn2+ surface cations active in PDH [10]. While those catalysts feature high initial activity, their initial propene selectivity is low (ca. 6–16 %). With time on stream those catalysts deactivate, which is accompanied by the increase in propene selectivity that reaches that of the Cr2O3/Al2O3 catalyst (ca. 85–90 %). We report herein that the introduction In+ and Mn2+ modifiers to the CVD-derived zinc-alumina catalysts affects significantly the catalytic properties of Zn2+ active sites. The experimental design of our study is based on the following considerations. Our previous work has uncovered that Zn/Al2O3 materials prepared by CVD of zinc on alumina dehydroxylated at higher temperatures gave catalysts with lower zinc content (ca. 1.7 wt.%) that exhibited higher specific activity and selectivity compared to the catalysts prepared by the same method but using alumina dehydroxylated at lower temperatures (which gave higher zinc content in the respective materials, ca. 5.6 wt.%) [10]. We attributed those differences to distinct local structures of Zn2+ sites in low and high Zn-content Zn/Al2O3 catalysts. Taking into account the notably high initial activity of the catalysts and the low initial propene selectivity, we hypothesized that at the early stages of the reaction (i.e., at a low time on stream, TOS), the active Zn2+ cations are not site-isolated and are therefore affecting each other, which contributes to the occurrence of the undesirable cracking and hydrogenolysis side reactions that deplete the selectivity to propene. To achieve the site isolation of Zn2+ active sites, we have now investigated if the introduction of catalytically inactive metals cations such In+ and Mn2+ can increase the site isolation of Zn2+ active sites and thereby improve their catalytic performance. The choice of In+ as a surface modifier (“diluent”) is motivated by our previous studies that showed that indium oxide supported on alumina interacts with surface hydroxyls, in conditions of H2 treatment, by replacing the surface protons and forming the surface In+ cations [11,12]. In addition, given the amphoteric nature of indium oxide, it can be expected that it will modify the acidic properties of alumina to a lesser extent than alkali metals cations. In turn, MnO, being a low-valent oxide, possesses weak basic properties and is expected to interact with the surface hydroxyls of alumina to form Mn2+ surface cations by replacing protons of the surface hydroxyls of alumina. Importantly, in contrast to alkaline-earth bivalent metal oxides, MnO does not form highly stable carbonates and MnO is not reducible to Mn0 even at high temperatures (above 1000 K). Thus, the hydrogen treatment of MnO x /Al2O3 leads to Mn2+, which is stable in hydrogen above 900 K [13,14]. In brief, we hypothesized that the dilution (i.e., increased site-isolation) of cationic active sites in the PDH catalysts based on supported metal oxides can impact the propene selectivity in a similar way as has been demonstrated for Pt-based bimetallic catalysts, such as Pt-Sn [15–18], Pt-Ga [19–22], Pt-In [23–25], Pt-Ge [26,27], Pt-Zn [28,29] or Pt-Cu [30,31]), where the second metal enables the site-isolation of the Pt sited in the respective bimetallic alloy. Indeed, Pt–Pt ensembles are known to catalyze the cracking and hydrogenolysis side reactions [1], and the site-isolation of the surface of Pt atoms by the dilution of Pt surface with inactive metals atoms mentioned above inhibits these undesired side reactions in PDH [15]. Conceptually, a related effect was recently reported for unsupported mixed oxides (Ga,Al)2O3. The increase of Al in those solid solution catalysts lead to the site-isolation of the active Ga3+ sites in the tetrahedral positions of the crystalline oxide lattice surrounded predominantly by the Al3+ ions, and this correlated with the increased propene selectivity in PDH [32]. In what follows, we discuss our results towards the assessment if a similar effect (i.e., the increased propene selectivity in PDH) can be achieved when active cationic sites are diluted with inactive ones on the alumina surface. Experimental section Materials PURAL BT hydroxide of aluminum (bayerite) from SASOL was used to prepare η-Al2O3 support by the calcination of bayerite at 800 K for 2 h. The formation of η-Al2O3 was confirmed by X-ray diffraction (Fig. 1 ) [33]. The BET specific surface area of η-Al2O3 evaluated from the N2 physisorption was 360 m2 g−1. Five different Zn/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared and characterized in this work. Four Zn/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared using the high-temperature (ca. 713 Κ) interaction of zinc vapor with the alumina support (CVD deposition), following our experimental protocol utilized previously [9]. Specifically, Zn/η-Al2O3, two ZnIn/η-Al2O3 catalysts with indium loading of 4 wt.% and 6 wt.%, and ZnMn/η-Al2O3 catalyst with Mn content 0.9 wt.% were prepared relying on CVD to deposit Zn. In addition, one ZnIn/η-Al2O3 catalyst was prepared by the conventional incipient wetness impregnation (IWI) approach. Indium- and manganese-containing alumina (denoted as In/η-Al2O3 and Mn/η-Al2O3) were prepared as follows. First, indium or manganese was introduced by the IWI of alumina with an aqueous solution of indium or manganese nitrate, followed by drying in ambient conditions for 20 h and then at 380 K for 10 h and, finally, calcination in the flow of dry air at 773 K for 2 h. The calcined materials were outgassed at 713 K for 2 h in a vacuum glass cell and then treated in H2 at 713 K for 2 h. The H2 treatment was conducted in static conditions, using three cycles of exposure of the materials to 1 bar of H2 for 30 min and evacuation to 10−4 Torr in-between the H2 exposures. Following the reductive treatment in H2, the materials were outgassed for 2 h at 713 K and zinc CVD conducted at 713 K. The concentrations of indium and manganese were chosen to be no more than half the concentration of surface hydroxyls remaining on the surface of η-Al2O3 after evacuation at 713 K. For the preparation of the ZnIn/η-Al2O3 catalyst by the impregnation method, an aqueous solution containing nitrates of indium and zinc was prepared with the concentrations of zinc and indium salts tailored to target 6 wt.% of zinc and 4 wt.% of indium in the impregnated material. Following the impregnation, the material was dried, calcined and reduced similar to In/η-Al2O3 and Mn/η-Al2O3 materials. Notations of thus-prepared materials are Zn; ZnIn-1; ZnIn-2; ZnMn and ZnIn-imp, respectively. The specific surface area of all the catalysts prepared listed in Table 1 . Catalysts characterization The materials prepared were characterized using diffuse reflectance infrared (DRIFT) spectroscopy of adsorbed CO and H2 probe molecules. The DRIFT spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Protege 360 spectrometer (spectral resolution was 4 cm−1) equipped with a homemade DR attachment [34]. The adsorption of carbon monoxide and hydrogen was performed at room temperature at the equilibrium pressure of 2.7 and 6.7 kPa (20 and 50 Torr) respectively. The amount of coke formed on the catalysts after the catalytic tests were measured by the Perkin Elmer CHN analyzer (2400 Series-II). Zinc content in the catalysts prepared via CVD was determined by AAS spectroscopy using the ContrAA 700 instrument of Analytik Jena AG. The catalysts composition is listed in Table 1. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) powder patterns of γ-Al2O3 and η-Al2O3 were recorded on DRON-3 X-ray diffractometer, using a Cu Ka radiation source (λ = 1.5406 Ǻ) and a nickel filter in the range of 10–80°. Catalytic tests PDH tests were conducted using a U-shape fixed bed quartz reactor (30 cm long, 15 mm i.d.) at 823 K under atmospheric pressure. The catalysts prepared (0.78 g, volume of 1 cm3, grain size 0.25–0.5 mm) were loaded into the reactor in a glovebox under argon atmosphere. The feed gas consisted of a mixture of propane and nitrogen 15 M % C3H8. The feed gas was supplied to the reactor at the inlet flow of 0.93 L h−1 at STP after having passed through the activated moisture- and oxygen-removing traps (dehydroxylated alumina and reduced copper-zinc-alumina sorbents, respectively). All the catalytic tests were carried out in the kinetic region. The part of the reactor above the catalyst bed was filled with quartz chips to improve the preheating of the feed. The products of the reaction were analyzed using a gas chromatograph (LKhM-8MD), PORAPAK-Q and 5A molecular sieves columns and a thermal conductivity (TCD) detector. The conversion of propane and the propene selectivity were calculated based on the carbon atom balance principle according to the equations: (1) C 3 H 8 conversion = ( C 3 H 8 , in − C 3 H 8 , out × N 2 , in N 2 , out ) C 3 H 8 , in (2) C 3 H 6 selectivity = C 3 H 6 , out × N 2 , in N 2 , out ( C 3 H 8 , in − C 3 H 8 , out × N 2 , in N 2 , out ) where C3H8,in and C3H8,out are the concentrations of propane at the reactor inlet and reactor outlet respectively; C3H6,out is the concentration of propene at the reactor outlet; N2,in and N2,out are N2 concentrations at the reactor inlet and outlet respectively. Molecular simulation Theoretical simulations using a cluster developed based on the model of η-Al2O3 reported in [35] were conducted to make assessments of the influence of diluting cations on the properties of Zn2+ active sites. The coordinates of the primitive unit cell of η-E-Al2O3 were used for the construction of η-E-Al2O3 cluster for further simulations. To do this, the unit cell was replicated along the a direction, and from the resulting structure a smaller cluster of the stoichiometry H*33Al24O53 was extracted. Here H* denotes terminal hydrogen atoms passivating dangling AlO bonds. The geometry of the cluster was optimized within DFT approach using B2LYP hybrid functional. The surface cation Zn2+ was introduced onto the surface of the cluster by replacing two neighboring protons of the surface hydroxyl groups, and the surface cation In+ adjacent to Zn2+ replaced one proton of a surface hydroxyl. Mn2+ was introduced by substitution of two neighboring protons of the surface OH groups (instead of In+ cation). H, O, Al, Zn and Mn atoms were treated with 6–31G(d,p) basis set while In atom was treated with LanZ2DZ effective core potential basis set. For further optimization, only the zinc coordinates, the coordinates of the diluting atoms, and the coordinates of the oxygen atoms bonded to zinc or the diluting atoms were optimized, and the coordinates of the rest of the cluster were frozen. Anharmonic correction was not applied when calculating frequencies. The GAUSSIAN-16 program [36] was used throughout this work. Results and discussion Catalysts characterization by DRIFT spectroscopy of adsorbed CO and H2 The surface properties of the prepared materials were first assessed by DRIFTS. Fig. 2 presents DRIFT spectra of the parent alumina (trace a) and the same alumina, modified with In+ and Mn2+ cations (traces b, c and d), in the OH stretching vibrations region. It can be seen that introduction of indium and manganese onto the surface of alumina by impregnation and subsequent reduction, as described above, results in the substitution of a part of surface protons of the alumina by In+ or Mn2+ cations. Indeed, the intensities of the IR bands due to surface hydroxyls of the alumina decrease after indium or manganese introduction. In particular, the higher the content of the introduced indium the lower the concentration of surface hydroxyls is retained. This can be seen by the comparison of the spectra of OH groups of indium-modified alumina with different indium loadings (Fig. 2, traces b and c). Worthy of note, the nominal loading of the In+ and Mn2+ diluting cations in ZnIn-1 and ZnMn catalysts is chosen to replace the same amount of surface hydroxyls by In+ and Mn2+ cations (after the H2 treatment) in 4 %In/η-Al2O3 and 0.9 % Mn/η-Al2O3 supports (Table 1), and this indeed can be seen from the comparable intensity of the residual hydroxyls in the corresponding IR spectra (orange b and green d traces in Fig. 2). Further, the impact of In and Mn on the Lewis acid surface sites of dehydroxylated alumina was probed by DRIFTS of adsorbed CO. Fig. 3 shows the DRIFT spectra of CO adsorbed on the parent alumina (trace a), as well as on the alumina modified with indium (trace b) and manganese (trace c), reduced in hydrogen and evacuated at 713 K. The bands at 2202 and 2235 cm−1 in the spectrum of CO adsorbed on parent alumina are due to CO adsorption on different Al3+ sites on the surface of alumina [37]. The introduction of indium or manganese is accompanied by a decrease of the concentration of the Al3+ Lewis sites, in particular, the strongest Al3+ Lewis sites characterized by the band at 2235 cm−1 disappear in 4 % In/η-Al2O3 and 0.9 % Mn/η-Al2O3 (Fig. 3). This can be explained by the substitution of the surface protons by In+ or Mn2+ cations (In+ and Mn2+ primarily substitute the protons of those hydroxyls, the removal of which during dehydroxylation gives strong Lewis sites). In the case of manganese-modified alumina, new sites characterized by a band at 2191 cm−1 in the spectrum of adsorbed CO (weaker Lewis sites) are formed; these sites should be assigned to the Mn2+ surface cations [38]. At the same time, a high-frequency shoulder due to CO adsorbed on the residual Al3+ sites (at about 2200 cm−1) can be seen. Thus, it is seen that in the alumina doped with indium, part of the Lewis Al3+ sites is suppressed, and in the alumina doped with Mn, part of the Lewis Al3+ sites is replaced by weaker Mn2+. The formation of In+ surface cations upon reduction in hydrogen and substitution of surface protons H+ on different supports was reported previously [11,12]. The stabilization of Mn2+ surface species upon reduction of the alumina-supported manganese oxide was reported in the literature as discussed above in the Introduction section. We believe that since the concentration of the introduced modifying cations In+ and Mn2+ is significantly lower than that of surface OH groups before the introduction of these cations, how it follows from Fig. 2, they are sufficiently distant from each other, which makes it possible to place Zn2+ ions between them by zinc CVD. The deposition of zinc on η-Al2O3, In/η-Al2O3 and Mn/η-Al2O3 by the CVD method led to a further decrease in the intensity of the bands of surface OH groups, owing to the substitution of surface protons by Zn2+ cations (Fig. 4 ). More specifically, the intensities of the bands due to the residual hydroxyls in the CVD-derived Zn catalysts (traces b–e) are negligible compared to those of η-Al2O3, preevacuated at 713 K (trace a). Table 1 reports numbers of the surface protons replaced by Zn2+, In+ and Mn2+ cations introduced. Compared with these catalysts, the bimetallic catalyst prepared by impregnation method (ZnIn-imp) shows a higher concentration of residual OH groups (trace f). This result indicates that in this catalyst a significantly lower proportion of zinc interacts with the hydroxyl groups of the support, forming lower concentration of Zn2+ active sites. Fig. 5 shows DRIFT spectra of CO adsorbed on all of the zinc-containing catalyst prepared (after evacuation at 713 K). The spectra feature mainly by the absorption bands at ca. 2200 cm−1. As reported by us previously [10], the absorption bands around 2200 cm−1 in the IR spectra of zinc-alumina catalysts can be associated with surface Zn2+ cations [39,40]. Interestingly, the intensity of the CO absorption bands in the spectra of prepared catalysts decreases in line with the expected surface density of Zn2+ bonded to the surface of alumina. The lower concentration of Zn2+ surface sites in the CVD-derived catalysts modified with In and Mn dopants is explained by the replacement of surface hydroxyls of alumina by In+ or Mn2+ cations, making in turn less of surface hydroxyls available for the reaction with Zn vapor. In the case of ZnIn-Imp, a part of zinc is expected to be in the forms of ZnO particles or zinc-alumina spinel [41,42]. The exact positions of the peaks in the spectra of CO adsorbed on prepared catalysts vary. In addition, the shape of some bands is asymmetric (especially for Zn, ZnIn-1 and ZnMn catalysts). The difference in the exact peak positions in the CO-FTIR spectra of our catalysts can be due to the somewhat different strength of Zn2+ Lewis acid sites, which in turn is due to their different local environment. For instance, the band at 2199 cm−1 in the spectrum of CO adsorbed on the ZnMn catalyst is broader compared to those in the spectra of CO adsorbed on ZnIn catalysts. This is likely an effect of overlapping bands due to CO adsorbed on Zn2+ and Mn2+ cations. The high-frequency shoulder in the spectra of CO adsorbed on the Zn catalyst can be because of inhomogeneity of Zn2+ sites as well as due to CO adsorbed on the residual strong Al3+ Lewis acid sites. Unfortunately, the peak positions in the spectra of adsorbed CO differ too little for drawing unambiguous conclusions about the effect of the diluting cations the properties of Zn2+ active sites. Indeed, the peak position of CO adsorbed on Zn catalyst is slightly higher than that of other CVD samples, while the peak positions of CO adsorbed on ZnIn and ZnMn samples are similar. To deepen our understanding of the Zn2+ sites in the prepared materials, we turned to the hydrogen probe molecule. It has been reported that Zn2+ surface cationic sites on different supports are active in hydrogen dissociation at ambient and moderately elevated temperatures, which results in the formation of surface zinc hydride species (ZnH) and hydroxyl groups, i.e., heterolytic hydrogen dissociation [10,43]. Fig. 6 displays DRIFT spectra of ZnH hydrides formed as the result of H2 adsorption and dissociation on Zn2+ cations in the catalysts studied. It can be seen that the spectra of the surface hydride ZnH species are characterized by the bands with significantly different band shapes and peak positions. All the spectra consist of several poorly resolved absorption bands with a tailing to low frequencies. The spectrum of the ZnH species of the single component Zn catalyst (trace a) is most intense and is characterized by the peak position at 1878 cm−1. The introduction of indium leads to a notable decrease in the contribution of the high-frequency component of the spectrum of surface hydrides; in addition, a sharp peak (overlapping with the broad one) appears at 1836 cm−1 (trace b). A higher amount of indium introduced to the alumina support entails a smaller amount of Zn introduced by CVD and, accordingly, a lower concentration of ZnH hydride species formed upon the dissociation of hydrogen (i.e., lower intensity of the ZnH hydride band) (trace c). The introduction of manganese to enhance the isolation of Zn2+ active sites in the ZnMn catalyst leads to the formation of Zn2+-H species which are characterized by somewhat higher ZnH vibration frequencies as compared to those in ZnIn-1 and ZnIn-2, i.e., the respective band in the ZnMn catalyst is observed at 1866 cm−1 (Fig. 6, trace d). In this case, the frequencies of the ZnH vibrations of surface zinc hydrides are more close to those of the single-component Zn catalyst. These distinct ZnH frequencies of the catalysts prepared indicate a significant impact of the diluting cations on the properties of the active Zn2+ sites. In particular, varying ZnH frequencies indicate a different strength of the ZnH bond and, accordingly, the strength of the bond between the Zn2+ cations and the support surface. The introduction of the In+ or Mn2+ cations to improve the isolation of active Zn2+ sites can result in both geometric and electronic (chemical) effects. However, a significantly larger low-frequency shift in the ZnH frequencies induced by the presence of In+ cations (42 cm−1 relative to the single-component Zn catalyst) as compared to Mn2+ cations (22 cm−1 relative to the single-component Zn catalyst) may indicate that the electronic (chemical) effect of the diluting is significant. To make assessment of the electronic impact of dopant ions on the Zn2+ active sites properties we performed simplified molecular simulation of Al2O3 cluster (of the stoichiometry H33Al24O53) with bonded Zn2+ and/or In+ cations (Fig. 7 ). The simulation details are reported in the experimental section. It has been found that the Mulliken charge of single Zn2+ cation bonded to the alumina cluster (position I) equals 0.6775 (Table 2 ). When an additional In+ cation was placed on the cluster surface (position II) the Mulliken charge of Zn2+ decreased to 0.5833. When Mn2+ cation was placed on the cluster surface instead of In+ the Mulliken charge of Zn2+ cation in the position I was found to be 0.6697. Thus it can be seen that the electronic effect of In+ or Mn2+ dopants on the charge of Zn2+ active site is significant. This means that the Lewis acidity strength can be affected by different cationic dopants. In particular, the presence of In+ cations leads to a more significant decrease in the Lewis acidity of Zn2+ sites, while the effect of Mn2+ is less. Furthermore, it can be seen from Table 2 that two neighboring Zn2+ sites can affect each other and their strength significantly depends on their position on the surface of Al2O3. Thus, the results of the simulation provide additional evidence of the existence of an electronic (chemical) effect, which, in turn, indicates the presence of a geometric effect of dilution of active sites with dopant ions. The calculated ZnH vibration frequencies (Table 2) within the simulation approximations applied are also in general agreement with the spectroscopic results reported above. Somewhat higher ZnH vibration frequency calculated in the presence of neighboring In+ cation compared to the IR results may be related to the simplified simulation approach (chosen basis sets, cluster size, Zn2+ or In+ positions). Next, we also studied reducibility of Zn2+ sites in three of the prepared catalysts Zn, ZnIn-1 and ZnMn in the presence of hydrogen at the temperature of 773 K. The catalysts were heated in static conditions in the IR ampoule in hydrogen at 773 K and at the pressure of 20 Torr (approximately average partial pressure of hydrogen during the catalytic run at 773 K). Fig. 8 shows IR spectra of CO adsorbed on Zn2+ sites in Zn, ZnIn-1 and ZnMn catalysts before and after heating in hydrogen and subsequent evacuation at 773 K. In the case of ZnMn catalyst the band at 2191 cm−1 due to CO adsorption on Mn2+ cations was subtracted based on the corresponding spectrum in Fig. 3. It can be seen that a significant part of Zn2+ sites in all the catalysts is reducible under the given conditions. In the case of Zn catalyst, the concentration of Zn2+ sites decreased nearly twice, while in the case of ZnIn-1 and ZnMn catalysts the decrease is somewhat less. The absorption of hydrogen due to breaking ZnO bonds with the support occurs most significantly only during the first several minutes. It is interesting to note that repeated injection of hydrogen (after the first heating at 773 K) nearly did not affect the concentration of Zn2+ sites. This indicated that only part of these sites is instable under reduction conditions. The reducibility of Zn2+ active site in alumina-supported zinc catalysts were reported in our previous work [10]. It was also shown that in these catalysts the stability of Zn2+ sites depends on the preparation conditions (and corresponding zinc content). The negative effect of hydrogen (reduction of active sites) was also reported for silica-supported cobalt dehydrogenation catalysts [44]. In that case, however, active Co(II) sites can be restored by heating in flowing inert gas at high temperatures. In the case of supported zinc catalysts a reducible part of zinc gradually leave catalysts because of the volatility of zinc(0). PDH tests We have first evaluated the catalytic activity of the Zn-free alumina-supported indium and manganese materials subjected to the reduction treatment at 713 K and found these supports nearly inactive relative to zinc-containing catalysts. Fig. 9 shows propane conversion and propene selectivity as a function of time on stream for the single-component Zn catalyst and two-component ZnIn-1, ZnIn-imp and ZnMn catalysts. Results demonstrate that CVD-derived catalysts exhibit approximately similar activity in propane conversion, showing specific rates of 1.37, 1.72 and 1.60 (mol/h/mol Zn) obtained for Zn, ZnIn-1 and ZnMn, respectively (Table 3 , Fig. 9). At the same time, the selectivity of the ZnIn-1 catalyst for propene is significantly higher than that of the single-component Zn catalyst. Taking into account that the zinc content in this catalyst is lower than in the one-component Zn catalyst (Table 1), it can be concluded that the dilution of Zn2+ active sites with surface In+ cations with an optimized concentration of In improves the selectivity of the catalyst without loss (even some gain) of its activity. Side reactions such as cracking and hydrogenolysis which result in methane, ethene and ethane by-products formation are significantly suppressed, especially at the initial stage of the catalytic run. The effect of the dilution of Zn2+ active sites by In+ cations is more clearly manifested at the initial stage of the catalytic test where cracking/hydrogenolysis side reactions are significantly suppressed compared to the single-component Zn catalyst. This behavior is similar to that in Pt-based bimetallic PDH catalyst in which surface Pt atoms are site-isolated in bimetallic alloys with catalytically inactive metals (Sn, Ga, In, etc.). It is interesting to note that catalytic performance of the ZnMn catalyst is somewhat different compare to that of ZnIn-1. The catalytic activity of this catalyst is lower than that of Zn and ZnIn-1, yet the propene selectivity of the ZnMn catalyst is somewhat higher than that of the Zn catalyst, but worse than that of ZnIn-1 (Table 1, and Fig. 1). Several factors may be in play to impact the distinct catalytic properties of ZnIn-1 and ZnMn catalysts. One consideration is related to a lower extent of site isolation of the Zn2+ active sites in the ZnMn catalyst relative to the ZnIn catalyst. Alternatively, since Mn2+ cations are Lewis acidic, Mn2+ sites may combine with Zn2+ sites to enable side reactions such as cracking/hydrogenolysis and coke formation. Furthermore, catalysts containing Mn2+ have been reported to participate in the coke formation [45–49]. Thus, the lower activity of the ZnMn catalyst compared to ZnIn-1 and the rapid decrease in activity at the initial stage of the catalytic experiment may be due to the Lewis acidity of Mn2+ cations, evidenced also in our CO adsorption experiments. Table 3 represents catalytic data on the propane conversion and propene selectivity of the prepared catalysts measured after operating the catalysts at 773 K for300 min and at the beginning of the catalytic run (15 min) , as well as coke content measured after the catalytic run (at 773 K and then at 823 K). It can be seen that the introduction of the modifying metal cations, in addition to better propene selectivity, also reduces coke formation. This is especially pronounced in the case of ZnIn catalysts. It is seen also that the concentrations of diluting cations in ZnIn-1 and in ZnMn catalysts are close to optimal. An increase in the content of the diluting cations leads to a significant decrease in propane conversion because of lower zinc deposition, although the propene selectivity increases less significantly. Fig. 10 shows catalytic behavior of ZnIn-2 catalyst (6 % In loaded) compared to that of ZnIn-1. It can be seen that the steady state conversion (at the end of the catalytic run at 773 K) of ZnIn-2 (6 wt.% In) is 20 % lower than that of ZnIn-1 (4 wt.% In), although the corresponding propene selectivities differ less significantly. Next, Table 2 shows zinc content in all freshly-prepared catalysts and the same catalysts after testing at 773 K. It can be seen that the zinc content in all catalysts (except of ZnIn-imp) decreased. However, the decrease is less than expected from the above results on the heating of the catalysts in hydrogen in the vacuum cell. This can be because that the feed flow is slow and therefor reduced (zero-valent) zinc can reversibly interact with the surface OH groups of alumina. Finally, the ZnIn-imp catalyst, prepared by a traditional incipient wetness impregnation technique, exhibit poor catalytic behavior compared to ZnIn-1or even ZnIn-2 catalysts, prepared by zinc CVD deposition. This is seen from Table 2 and Fig. 9 Relative catalytic activity in propane conversion is significantly lower than that of ZnIn-1or ZnIn-2. It was reported in our previous study that steady state catalytic activity of a single-component Zn-imp catalyst prepared by the impregnation technique was comparable with that of Zn-CDV catalysts [9]. The low catalytic activity of the ZnIn-imp catalyst can be explained by the competitive interaction of indium and zinc with surface OH groups. Indium oxide under reduction conditions is easily reduced to In0, which interacts better with surface hydroxyls than zinc oxide particles, and thereby suppresses the formation of active cationic Zn2+ sites. Thus the formation Zn2+ active sites bonded to the alumina surface which are formed due to the interaction of ZnO particles with surface OH groups, is partially inhibited by the presence of In+ cations. The result of the catalytic tests thus indicated that the diluting of Zn2+ active sites by catalytically inactive surface cations to make them more isolated favors the catalytic properties of the supported zinc catalysts. The diluting of Zn2+ sites can significantly suppresses side reaction such as cracking/hydrogenolysis, coke deposition. Unfortunately the catalytic stability of all the catalysts is not high and the catalysts deactivate significantly during the catalytic run. This can be mainly because of reduction of significant part of zinc mainly because of weak bonding to the surface of alumina. In addition, surface Lewis acidity of alumina also results in the catalysts deactivation due to coke formation. From this point of view the use of different supports which provide stronger interaction of zinc active sites with their surface and possess in lower Lewis acidity can be favorable [9]. Nevertheless the approach for the active sites isolation in different catalysts containing Men+ active sites proposed in this study can be useful for the development of efficient alkane dehydrogenation catalyst Conclusions In summary, in the present work we investigated alumina supported zinc-based PDH catalysts in which the surface Zn2+ active sites are isolated (diluted) by catalytically inactive surface In+ or Mn2+ cations, thereby improving their catalytic behavior. The catalysts were characterized by DRIFT spectroscopy of adsorbed carbon monoxide and hydrogen probe molecules and tested in propane dehydrogenation. It has been found that ZnH frequencies of the surface hydrides formed upon the dissociation of H2 on Zn2+ cations are significantly affected by the nature of the surface-modifying cations (In+ or Mn2+).The influence of the modifying cations on the strength of the ZnH bond in these hydrides can be due to both geometric and electronic effects. The electronic effect was confirmed by the molecular DFT simulation. The modifying cations significantly affect the catalytic properties of the Zn2+ active sites so that the introduction of In+ diluting cations significantly improves the propene selectivity of the ZnIn/η-Al2O3 catalysts and increase the steady-state specific activity. Unlike In+ cations, the introduction of Mn2+ cations results in somewhat smaller improvement effect. The selectivity of the ZnMn catalyst is lower that of ZnIn-1 while higher than that of the single component Zn catalyst. Such a different behavior can be due to somewhat different electronic and geometric effects of the In+ or Mn2+ cations. In addition, Mn2+ surface cations, being surface Lewis acid sites, may have their own catalytic activity in the side reactions such as coke formation or catalyze propane cracking/hydrogenolysis reactions in a pair of neighboring Zn2+ sites. The results described herein can be used to develop improved catalysts for alkane dehydrogenation by the optimization of the isolation between active sites by the introduction of different surface cations which are inactive in the dehydrogenation reaction. The introduction of such cations can significantly improve the catalytic behavior of dehydrogenation catalysts which active sites are supported surface cations such as Zn2+, Cr3+, Ga3+. We believe that our approach can help in design of the new or improved alkane dehydrogenation catalysts with better selectivity and lower coking. CRediT authorship contribution statement Yury A. coredata.dc:description: Supported zinc-containing catalysts are considered as a viable alternative to the currently-deployed Cr-based (toxic) and Pt-based (costly) catalysts of alkane dehydrogenation, as reflected also in the increased number of reports related to the Zn-based catalysts in recent years. Here, we present a study of alumina-supported Zn-In and Zn-Mn propane dehydrogenation (PDH) catalysts prepared by the tailored methods. Specifically, the introduction of zinc relied on the chemical vapor deposition (CVD, using Zn vapor) onto alumina or alumina-supported indium or manganese materials, the latter two prepared by the impregnation of alumina with aqueous solutions of the respective metal nitrates followed by the calcination and hydrogen treatment. Alternatively, both zinc and indium were introduced by the co-impregnation of alumina with aqueous zinc and indium nitrates. The PDH tests revealed that the “dilution” of the active Zn2+ surface sites with In+ cations lead to a significant improvement in the catalytic performance, i.e., the introduction of In+ increased propene selectivity and attenuated the undesirable cracking and hydrogenolysis side reactions as well as decreased coke formation. In contrast, Mn2+ cations improved the catalytic properties of Zn2+ surface sites to a lesser extent than In+ cations. All prepared catalysts were characterized by DRIFT (diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform) spectroscopy of the adsorbed CO and H2 probe molecules. It was found that surface In+ and Mn2+ cations affect Zn2+ sites (electronic and geometric effect), which can be assessed from the position of the IR bands of zinc hydridespecies, formed due to the heterolytic hydrogen dissociation on the Zn2+ active sites. The effect of In and Mn dopants also was confirmed by the molecular DFT simulation.
coredata.dc:title: The impact of indium and manganese modifiers on the catalytic properties of zinc-alumina propane dehydrogenation catalysts
